Hi Michael,
Yes, I have turned off the frontier. 
It kind of acts like house cleaning.   
(Turn off the frontier for a day, it munches through the system)

The patch I will be pestering Joe (yeah, and you, too)
more to do is some more intelligence in the database.
For example, it appears to sort of keep entries for diversions,
and includes this in the count.  Doesn't sound like much,
but the numbers get huge, and clog the system.  With the frontier
off, they fall off the count.  Its fun to watch the count of
downloaded + queued drop fast.

Throughput falls on its face though, something to do with not
following up on a current web site in the frontier.  Cause, duh,
new stuff isn't appearing on the frontier.

John


Michael Stack wrote:

> Have you tried disabling the FrontierScheduler once the crawler goes
> past 120M fetched? You might even be able to set the disabled flag from
> JMX. If so, since you can get counts of crawled and queued via JMX, you
> could automate switching off the processor.
>
> Otherwise, do you have a patch for the below for us to apply Joe?
>
> St.Ack
>
> joehung302 wrote:
> >
> > Hi,
> >
> > We've been using heritrix with crawl map for crawling > 1B urls. We
> > current have 8 crawl machines at one time.
> >
> > Under this configuration, the crawl can only be successful if the
> > crawlers don't fail. Hence we're really focused on how to keep the
> > crawler running as long as possible.
> >
> > We thought it might be a good idea to *limit* bdb growth after
> > certain size. And we also know that bdb size has a lot to do with
> > the to-be-crawled URL list. Hence the question: Does it make sense
> > to set a upper limit on the Frontier so, when the to-be-cralwed URL
> > reached a certain number (say, 120M urls), stop collecting to-be-
> > crawled and throw any new links away? The idea is, in order to
> > download 120M URLs, we probably would have a to-be-crawled list of
> > 400M, and bdb probably won't survive under that size.
> >
> > Does it make sense?
> >
> > cheers,
> > -Joe
> >
> >
>
>
